awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Charismatic Politicians, Weak Parties, and the Disruption of Democracy
awd_abstract_narration:
Democracy is facing may challenges around the world, from the erosion of long-held democratic norms in mature democracies like the United States, to renewed party system upheaval in Latin America and Eastern Europe, to the full-blown autocratic reversal in countries like Turkey or Thailand. This project studies how the obstacles that parties face in controlling their politicians interact with electoral rules, contextual conditions, and voter pressures to produce two phenomena that contribute to the erosion of democracy.  This project develops general theoretical arguments, collects data on parties and politicians from multiple countries, proposes new strategies to measure party system instability, politicians’ performance, and candidates’ charisma, and summarizes the findings in general policy recommendations. In contributing to the understanding of the causes behind democratic backsliding, the project will identify policies and institutional arrangements that are most conducive to stable political parties and healthy democracies, two key components of national prosperity and international peace.

The research program integrates three key components: theory development, empirical analysis and methodological innovation. The project develops a series of formal theoretical models that examine the understudied strategic interactions between political parties as longer-lived entities and their shorter-sighted individual candidates, under the premise that these interactions can help explain a variety of forms of democratic disruption.  The project develops new methodologies to capture hard-to-measure concepts of politician charisma, incumbent performance, and party strength.  Using a series of quasi-experimental approaches and natural experiments, a rich set of novel empirical implications derived from the formal models are tested with data from multiple countries. The analyses both validate the theories and produce systematic empirical evidence to inform scholarly and policy debates.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our grant advanced various projects intended to better understand the factors that have contributed to the erosion of democracy and democratic norms in both developed and developing democracies. Our primary focus was the role of political parties, studying the mechanisms by which the functioning of parties affects the health of democracy from both a theoretical and an empirical perspective.

Theoretically, we developed formal models to examine the strategic interactions between a longer-lived party and its shorter-lived candidates, emphasizing how this mismatch in time horizons and the unusually high appeal or charisma of some candidates can lead to diverging incentives that can in turn interact with institutional features such as term limits, political volatility, or societal polarization, and lead to parties' inability to cultivate its programmatic brands and prevent their incumbent candidates from trampling on democratic norms or from shirking in their provision of public goods.

Empirically, we complemented our theoretical investigation by focusing on two aspects: the measurement of hard-to-capture concepts, and the study of incumbency disadvantage. We developed an empirical measure of candidate charisma and an empirical measure of party strength. Our charisma measure uses large-scale text mining to collect news written about a politician, applies supervised machine learning to classify each text according to whether it contains charismatic terms, and then calculates, for every politician, the proportion of the news articles about them that contain charismatic terms. Our measure of party strength estimates the probability of candidates switching between running for a given party and running for another party, collects these probabilities in a transition matrix, and uses various novel indexes to characterize the stability of candidates’ affiliations to produce measures of continuity or strength at both the individual party level and the party system level. These two measures allow us and other researchers to characterize parties and politicians across the world. Finally, our empirical analysis documented that many political parties in Latin America are hurt electorally after winning elections---which we establish by focusing on close elections. This phenomenon, known as incumbency disadvantage, can be a symptom of democratic erosion. Our research established that this phenomenon is widespread in close elections in Latin America, proposed various explanations for its causes, and discussed the role of political parties and electoral institutions in the emergence of incumbency disadvantage in developing democracies.
